Klopp felt his team defended the visitors' set-piece threat pretty well and felt his side had enough opportunities to take the three points.

The Liverpool boss said: "We knew from the first second it would be a difficult job and it was clear we had a job to do.

"It was clear each set-piece would be a threat - our line-up was not the tallest - even in their own half, they made a proper set-piece off it when a free-kick or whatever was tehre.

"It was not too dangerous, just one proper situation when they had the header and Loris had to make the save. everything else we defended pretty well.

"Then we had the ball and that was the story of the game, we had it all the time."

Klopp felt his team started poorly with a lack of movement and were too laboured in their passing.

"The first half it looked a little bit stiff, the timing of the movements was not like it should have been.

"Passing was not that good, a little too late, not quick enough. Very often a static formation.

"But even in that half we had three or four chances. Two big chances and two we've already scored from this season.

"Second half was better, we changed system a few times to cause them more problems. Had good crosses, good chances to score the goal which was disallowed.

"It wasn't a night for three, four or five nil if you don't score early, that was clear.

"We waited for this one moment but it didn't happen. We have to accept it. If you don't score in football you always have to accept the result."

Klopp mentioned the Trent Alexander-Arnold cross which was headed poorly by Mo Salah and the Roberto Firrmino chance in the first half.

"Mo didn't hit the ball right, Sadio was at his back, I think both could have scored. Roberto first half. It was not a game for 20 chances but I think we had seven or eight. We all know the boys normally score in moments like this."

Jurgen Klopp felt his Liverpool side created enough chances to win the game against West Bromwich Albion at Anfield.

The Reds were forced to settle for a scoreless draw after a late Dominic Solanke effort was disallowed for handball while another effort from the young striker was cleared off the line.

Klopp made six changes from his derby line-up on Sunday and said he was sure about it just as he had been on Sunday.

"I made the decision and if we didn't win then it didn't work but that happens quite a lot in the life of a football manager.

"I was 100% convinced about this line-up like I was about the last line-up. But this time at least you cannot blame me for it. Probably will, we will see."

Klopp said of the disallowed goal decision: "Difficult. For me it was twice deflected and I'm still not sure if the hand hits the ball.

"For me it looks like chest. In the game it looks 100% like chest, afterwards when I saw a few replays, yeah there's an arm but I'm not sure whether he touched it with his arm.

"Is it a penalty in the other box? It's not on purpose for sure not. Must be a really good assistant, I think it was the assistant who made the decision - he will be happy probably if there was hand involved.

"That's another moment where we had no luck that's for sure. If he doesn't see it, or wasn't as sure as he obvioulsy was, then it's a goal, that's it.

Klopp went on to query some recent decisions against the Reds as well as the referee playing just three minutes of injury time in a game with six substitutions.

"I really don't know. A lot of things around ref decisions feel not good for us in the moment to be honest. We have the ball all the time but we have two offensive fouls before they had one foul.

"I don't get it really. But we cannot change anything obviously. And I told him (referee) after the game. Three minutes in a game like this - six changes, time-wasting from the first second from the opponent.

"He said it was right. What's my text then? They can do what they think is right in all the different moments and we have to accept it."
